comments.author: Nova King

comments.text:
The good news is that it takes a lot of grapes or raisins to cause a 
problem exact numbers are here (
http://www.vcahospitals.com/main/pet-health-information/article/animal-health/grape-and-raisin-toxicity-in-dogs/4397). 
My 84 lb American Bulldog would have to eat almost 3 lbs of grapes or close 
to a pound of raisins. This makes accidental poisonings with grapes much 
less common than chocolate which has a much lower toxic dose.

comments.author: Aemon z

comments.text:
We had a cat that LOVED getting the turkey leftovers-he meowed like crazy 
until he was fed. Everyone thought it was just so cute-until one day my Mom 
came home with the groceries for Thanksgiving and while putting them away 
realized she couldn't find the turkey!! She kept asking us kids if we had 
taken the turkey (really Mom?), and we thought she was just crazy. She kept 
swearing she had bought one, but we thought maybe with 9 small children she 
had gotten distracted and just thought she did. It took a few hours, but we 
finally realized the cat had come in while we were busy putting groceries 
away and dragged the 22lb turkey off into a corner, but off the plastic 
wrapper and had eaten at least a quarter of the turkey!! We were all so 
incredibly grossed out-my poor mother cried!! Even with a fresh, new 
turkey-we all pretty much lost our appetite for it that year!
comments.author: Geny R.

top_comment.text:
My dog eats table scraps & an all raw, red meat line of food. I joke that 
she eats healthier than I do and that she's on the paleolithic diet. 
Really, I just like the contents & variety of the line of food & she LOVES 
it. She gets so excited for feeding time, as if it were a dog treat. So it 
makes me believe it might actually contain most of what it says it does.﻿
top_comment.author: Katie Dubbs

comments.text: +seawarrior13 Fair enough! You are right about that.
comments.author: FYTJ

comments.text:
+FYTJ
I think you misread my comment as I never said that people who feed their 
dogs raw meat go out hunting. I was simply stating that raw meat from a 
fresh kill is much safer and healthier for a dog than raw meat that has 
been processed by humans.

Meat from a butcher shop is cut up on a table that had thousands of other 
cows or other animals laying on it that day; there are cases where the meat 
from one cow gets "glued" to other meat from several other cows 
(cross-contamination), and the meat also gets sprayed down with chemicals 
to "clean and disinfect" it. Meat from humans is much more dangerous for 
dogs to eat raw because of the cross-contamination and chemicals sprayed on 
it.
comments.author: seawarrior13

comments.text:
+seawarrior13
I believe that fire and cooking were earlier than the domestication of 
dogs. There are plenty sites where cooking was done that are much older 
than the 100,000 year date for dog domestication.


Although that does not mean they got a lot of cooked stuff as hunters would 
probably have let them have part of the kill at the time of the kill. I 
would expect dogs to get cooked bones and left overs.
comments.author: MacNutz2

comments.text:
+seawarrior13 So you're telling me all of these people who say they give 
raw meat to their dogs go out every morning, rifle in hand, and make a 
fresh kill to give to their pooches? Yeah, totally believable.
comments.author: FYTJ

comments.text:
+Galen Young

Depends if the raw meat was process by Humans or not.
comments.author: seawarrior13

comments.text:
+FYTJ

Dogs and wolves are the same species (C. lupus), that is why they are able 
to mate and produce offspring. In other words, dogs and wolves are pretty 
much the same and dogs can eat raw meat just fine.

The only reason eating raw meat increases their chances of contracting food 
borne illnesses is because of the way Humans process their meat. Not only 
can the ground beef you just bought from the store be months old, but when 
it was butchered, it was cut up along with several other animals and 
possibly glued together with other meat from a different cow/animal which 
leads to cross contamination.

I can go on and on about the way us Humans process their meat which is bad 
for dogs if eaten raw, but that would take too long. You can easily do some 
Google searches and find out. If dogs were to be out in the natural 
environment and eat a fresh kill just like a wolf, they'd be fine.
comments.author: seawarrior13

comments.text:
+seawarrior13 1st of all: Dogs are not wolves. 2nd of all: Yeah, humans are 
the only animals that cook their food. They're also the only animals with 
speech, culture and opposable thumbs so I would say cooking our food has 
served us pretty well.
comments.author: FYTJ

comments.text:
Dogs are fine on all raw meat diets.

2 day old roadkill is fine too. Their stomachs are far better at handling 
that stuff.
comments.author: Galen Young

comments.text:
+FYTJ
I don't see wolves killing a deer and then cooking the meat "on the 
barbie". Humans are the only animals that cook their food; all other 
animals on this planet eat their food raw.

I'm not saying that feeding your dog uncooked meat is perfectly safe - it 
just raises their risk of contracting foodborne illnesses. Granted, it's 
still MUCH safer for them to eat raw meat than it is for us Humans.
comments.author: seawarrior13

comments.text:
+Katie Dubbs Yeah, you're right, this IS youtube. And people chose to 
believe whatever poorly researched misinformation they find on here 
whenever it suits them.
comments.author: FYTJ

comments.text:
+FYTJ It's not the raw meat so much as the way it is prepared most of the 
time. I thought it was obvious that when we talk about eating raw food, we 
aren't talking about poultry or ground meats etc but I mean, this *is* 
YouTube.
comments.author: Katie Dubbs

comments.text:
+Galen Young The fact that they have been doing it forever does not mean 
it's healthier for them than cooked meat. The food Katie mentions is 
controlled so I'm guessing that is fine. But uncontrolled raw meat is 
dangerous to humans and dogs alike. Cooking meat kills off most of the 
microbial pathogens* that live in it, no need to be a rocket scientist to 
understand that.
(*such as salmonellas, escherichia coli, shigella, staphylococcus aureus, 
and listeria monocytogenes)

If you guys prefer to live off of raw meat though, be my guest. We'll see 
how that serves you when your brains turn to sponge because you contracted 
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. _'
comments.author: FYTJ

comments.text: +FYTJ That is 100% false. Dogs have eaten raw meat since forever.
comments.author: Galen Young

comments.text:
+FYTJ She's not eating raw chicken or ground meat. Raw cuts of beef and 
other red meats are perfectly safe for both humans and dogs. Ever had beef 
tataki or beef carpaccio? That's raw beef. It's also made by a Canadian dog 
cuisine company and is perfectly safe. Voted #1 for commercial dog food in 
every site I looked at.
comments.author: Katie Dubbs

comments.text: +FYTJ Her dog seems fine.
comments.author: Kyzan Hyuri

comments.text:
Raw meat is dangerous for dogs and humans alike. They can get some very 
nasty diseases from it and have a harder time digesting it than cooked 
food. Ask your vet!

captions.text:
Is there some evolutionary reason why dogs
eat out of a bag? Can we just feed the dang
dog our leftovers?! Let's SCIENCE THIS THING!

Hey pet people! This is DNews, I'm Trace.
Dogs are probably the oldest domesticated

animal, with mitochondrial DNA evidence suggesting
they split from wolves 100,000 years ago[a].

At the time, humans didn't have extra food
laying around, and would usually kill competing

carnivores like wolves. Smaller, less-aggressive
wolves would likely scavenge near human encampments,

eating from trash piles and snatching leftovers.
Over generations, humans purposefully fed

the cuter, friendlier wolves, and we set ourselves
on a path of domestication to create the dog.

But, if dogs evolved alongside humans, as
evidence suggests, then they were eating the

same things we were eating! But today, Americans
often avoid giving dogs, "People Food," so
what changed? In short, nothing.

As dogs and humans grew together, we shared
food. But, as human society advanced and pet

ownership grew, we couldn't simply feed them
table scraps in our cave. In 116 BCE, Marcus

Terentius Varro wrote a farming manual which
included advice for feeding working farm dogs

-- barley bread soaked in milk, and bones
from dead sheep. During the middle ages, common

families who needed work dogs, fed them whatever
was leftover -- so we're still following that

ancient system -- but by the 19th century,
Empress Tzu Hsi of China fed her dogs shark

fins, quail breasts and antelope milk, and
the royalty of Europe fed their pups roast

duck, cakes and candies. The rich got kinda
cray with their puppy chow.

During the Industrial Age, dog food started
to show up in the West as the middle class

prospered. As they cost both money and time,
pets were considered a luxury item, and people

wanted to show off their climbing of the socioeconomic
ladder by purchasing a prime pooch. Entrepreneurs

learned these nouveau caninophiles needed
help to feed their new friends -- and in the

1850s James Sprat of Cincinnati invented dog
biscuits from wheat, beet root and vegetables,

bound with beef blood. The dry food was a
hit, and by the 1920s canned wet food was

also in production -- it was mainly horse
meat, and by 1941 canned food was 90% of the

market. Then due to rationing during World
War II, dry food became hugely popular again.

At the same time, people around the world
still fed their dogs what they evolved to

eat, table scraps and leftover people food.
In the 1960s, to protect and grow their giant

industry, the Pet Food Institute, a lobbying
group for pet food -- campaigned the American

people by funding "scientific studies" and
running radio and TV ads touting the "dangers

of table scraps." Thus, we began to shy away
from feeding dogs the same things we were
eating.

However, dogs CAN EAT people food if it's
healthy. They probably shouldn't eat fast

food, or a mass of cheese (a little is okay),
or candy… But on the other hand, if you're

eating roasted chicken, green beans and potatoes…
Table scraps might not be so bad. Dogs can

safely eat flax, green beans, eggs, pumpkins,
peanut butter, carrots, apple slices, and

sweet potatoes… But they CAN'T eat chocolate,
coffee, yeast, alcohol. They can eat grains,

but they're better off with meats. And that's
not entirely off from where the pet food industry
is going.

These days, you can buy luxury dog food akin
to those Victorian princes and empresses -- duck,

squash, salmon, turkey and berries. It's literally
just PEOPLE food in dog packaging. Or if you'd

rather save some coin, you CAN stick to the
bagged dry food. A professor of veterinary

nutrition at Ohio State University says, his
students have studied the diet history of

thousands of animals and haven't found any
evidence that one dog food is better than
any other.

What do you feed your pet?
Tell us in the comments, and be sure you click

subscribe to get more science news every day
of the week. Thanks for watching!
